awd_titl_txt: CSBR: Natural History: Restructuring the Shirley C. Tucker Herbarium into a central hub for Louisiana botany via the consolidation of multiple herbaria
awd_abstract_narration:
Herbaria serve as crucial documentation of the natural world. Their dried, pressed specimens are of multidimensional importance: they are documentation of plant occurrence through space and time; markers of taxonomic and nomenclatural identity; evidence of plant-animal interactions; and sources of DNA for molecular studies. In recent years, there has been a resurgence in the acknowledgement of the importance of natural history specimens to modern biological research. Despite this resurgence and broad application of specimens in research a number of herbaria in Louisiana have recently closed and the collections orphaned. The Shirley C. Tucker Herbarium at Louisiana State University (LSU) has been the recipient of a large portion of these orphaned collections.  This has resulted in a near doubling in the size of the collection, from 207,500 specimens in 2015 to an estimated 400,000.  This project will result in the integration and consolidation of these specimens into the Tucker Herbarium's infrastructure, as well as completion of prior digitization efforts. This project will not only ensure that Louisiana's botanical heritage is available to interested researchers, but also foster an understanding of the importance of plants and natural history collections via outreach projects aimed at the broader public, undergraduate students, and the academic community.

The incorporation of multiple orphaned herbaria at LSU presents an opportunity to restructure the Tucker Herbarium into a regional hub for Louisiana botany.  This project will integrate the recently acquired herbarium specimens into LSU's compacted herbarium infrastructure, as well as consolidate multiple digital data sources.  Both of these steps are crucial for the maintenance and maximum utility of the much larger collection that will be housed at the Tucker Herbarium by 2020.  Challenges related to the integration of different filing schemes and database structures will be addressed by project personnel and their solutions will be presented at national conferences.  Additionally, continued digitization efforts will result in a nearly complete online database with image records of the Louisiana flora.  All associated data will be publicly accessible and linked to multiple consortium and data aggregation efforts, including SERNEC, iDigBio, and GBIF.  Integration and digitization activities will be coupled with the development of a rotating public exhibit to feature Tucker Herbarium research and activities, the inauguration of an annual plant biology seminar at LSU, and the establishment of a stronger presence, both online via social media campaigns and on campus via participation in outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Herbaria serve as crucial documentation of the natural world. Their dried, pressed specimens are of multidimensional importance: they are documentation of plant occurrence through space and time; markers of taxonomic and nomenclatural identity; evidence of plant-animal interactions; and sources of DNA for molecular studies. In recent years, there has been a resurgence in the acknowledgement of the importance of natural history specimens to modern biological research. In spite of the success of the digitization of nearly all the herbaria in Louisiana, cuts to budgets and space limitations have resulted in the shuttering of many of their doors. The Shirley C. Tucker Herbarium at Louisiana State University has been the recipient of a substantial portion of the collections within all these orphaned herbaria, with particularly large donations from Tulane University and University of Louisiana- Monroe. This has resulted in a near doubling in the size of the collection, from 207.5k specimens in 2015 to 400k in 2023.

Intellectual Merit: This project resulted in the integration and consolidation of these specimens into the LSU herbarium's physical infrastructure and improvements to the digital infrastructure through which specimen images and their associated data are available for use by public. Digital improvements included migrating and restructuring all collections management to relevant Symbiota web portals, implementation of a new server at LSU to host images, and development of a new LSU herbarium website to connect users to specimen portals and other relevant herbarium resources. The continued digitization efforts resulted in a comprehensive online database with image records of the Louisiana flora and their baseline occurrence data publicly accessible and linked to multiple consortia and data aggregation websites, including SERNEC, iDigBio, and GBIF. Details about our specific workflow have been shared with relevant communities that may also need to integrate physical and digital herbarium specimens through conference presentations and posters. This completed integration ensures that Louisiana's botanical heritage housed at LSU is available to interested researchers for decades to come.

Broader Impacts: This project was used as an opportunity to foster an understanding of the importance of plants and natural history collections via outreach projects aimed at the broader public, undergraduate students, and the academic community. A notable achievement funded through this NSF grant was the installation of an archival-grade display case outside of the LSU herbarium that has rotated through four student-designed displays on different botanical topics, including about the career of LSU professor emeritus Dr. Shirley C. Tucker and flora of the longleaf pine savanna of the southeastern US. This display case has increased the visibility of the herbarium at LSU and educated countless members of the LSU community about the important scientific collections they pass by every day. In addition, there have been over a dozen dedicated outreach events geared towards multiple communities, including events at the LSU Museum of Natural Sciences for families and children and a Virtual Lunchtime Lecture through the Botanical Research Institute of Texas that reached hundreds of curious members of the general public. In addition, activities funded through this grant have trained more than two dozen undergraduate students, a recent graduate, four graduate students, and four professionals.
